description.narrative: Resilience and Livelihoods/Durable Solutions for the Joint State Liaison Function (SLF-II) (Priority Area 1)

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of functional CBRMs in place 1.2 Number of conflicts resolved 1.3 Community events and forums organized 1.4 Number of return communities with functional community policing system 1.5 Number of farm protection committees in place 2.1 Number of communities assessed. 2.2 Number of dialogue forums organized on land use management. 2.3 Number of arbitrations supported 2.4 Number of Land information data centres established and are operational. 3.1 Number of RRR Coordinators deployed 3.2 Number of regular coordination meetings held 3.3 Number of verification and assessment missions organized 3.4 Number of staff who received training and materials by type. 4.1 Number of workshops organized 4.2 Number of people trained in micro-enterprise development (aggregated by gender) 4.3 Number of VSLAs established 4.4 Number of people receiving start-up grants through challenges launched 4.5 Type of support provided to APEX. 5.1: Number of workshops and seminars organized in support of local governance and decentralization policy and legislative reforms 5.2: Number of infrastructure and operational support provided to enhance operational effectiveness 5.3: Number of LGA and NA staff trained in participatory planning, implementation and monitoring 5.4: Number of trainings and institutional development support provided to CBOs. 5.5 Number of men and women with increased awareness on efficient use of natural resources and dangers of small arms 5.6: Number of youth at- risk and women benefitted from cash for work projects, vocational and viable micro enterprise business associations. 6.1 Number of community productive assets constructed 6.2 Number of people supported in value chain commodities 6.3 Number of producer associations established 6.4 Number of vulnerable households supported to recover assets.

1.1 10 functional CBRMs in place 1.1 At least 20 conflicts resolved 1.2 10 events and forums 1.3 10 return communities with functional community policing system 1.4 10 farm protection committees in place. 2.1 10 communities accessed 2.2 5 dialogue forums organized on land 2.3 5 arbitrations supported 2.4 Land information data centres and establish the information update system operational. meetings held. 3.2 5 verification and assessment missions organized 3.3 200 staff who received training and materials of which 30% female and 80% technical staff. 4.1 4 workshops organized and number of people trained 4.2 10 VSLAs established 4.3 100 people receiving start-up grants through challenges launched 4.4 Customized training and ICT equipment provided to APEX. 5.1 At least 100 staff at national and sub national level trained in various local governance related courses, polices and legislation disaggregated by sex. 5.2 At least 4 CBOs in pilot communities develop and operationalize a sustainability plan in a participatory and gender sensitive manner 5.3 At least 500 youth at risk and women in each pilot community benefit from short term employment with linkages to viable business associations/microenterprises. 5.4 At least 2 productive infrastructure projects rehabilitated/constructed in 2 pilot communities. 6.1 5 community productive assets established 6.2 2000 HHs supported in value chain commodities 6.3 20 producer associations established 6.4 1000 of vulnerable households supported to recover assets.

1.1 Implementation agreements with 5 partners concluded in 5 states; and work commenced in some states 1.1 Implementation agreements with 5 partners concluded in 5 states; and work commenced in some states 1.2 One Peace conference was conducted on reconciliation and peaceful coexistence and acceptance among the tribes of Kutum and Alwhaa 1.3 Implementation plan agreed with UNPOL and locations for implementation agreed upon. UNPOL prepared implementation workplan to commence the work 1.4 Implementation agreements with 5 partners concluded in 5 states; and work has begun in some states 2.1 9 communities have been assessed 3 in ND (Kutum, Kabkabya, Abugo) and 6 in East Darfur (Aldaen, Assalaya, Alferdous, Abu Jabra, Adila, Abukarinka) 2.2 LOAs between Peace Centers of University of Nyala and El-Fasher towards implementation of activities were signed and detail implementation plan for the two states is developed 2.3 LOAs between Peace Centers of University of Nyala and El-Fasher towards implementation of activities were signed and detail implementation plan for the two states is developed 2.4 Land information data centres and the information update system were established and operational 3.2 5 major inter-agency verification and assessments have been organized in the 4 states. 3.3 Procurement of items are on-going whilst training is being planned 4.1 on-going discussions with implementing partners to determine the best contractual options 4.2 Five (5) key implementing partners have been contracted to establish and support Voluntary Savings Associations 4.3 Five (5) key implementing partners have been contracted to establish and support Voluntary Savings Associations including provision of start-up grants 4.4 UNDP is already providing technical and logistic support to the Microfinance APEX in Darfur. In addition, UNDP is negotiating the deployment of an expert in the development of Cooperatives (SACO)_ which is an advanced system in Kenya and Ethiopia 5.1 5.2 Completed capacity building manuals for trainings, workshops, seminars and conferences 5.3 5.4 The Project has identified one key infrastructure i.e. on-going (rehabilitation of water dam in Tura community, El-Fasher Rural locality). Feasibility and the technical studies and drawings for the dam has been completed 6.1 identification of target beneficiaries (localities and communities is completed and procurement is process ongoing 6.2 Darfur-wide Value Chain Analysis completed and identified value chain commodities for support in South and East Darfur 6.3 Agreement with implementing partner is signed as well as targeted beneficiaries (at locality and community levels) is identified 6.4 Agreement with implementing partner is signed as well as targeted beneficiaries (at locality and community levels) is identified
The project has no planned activities in 2021.
The project has no planned activities in 2021.
The project has no planned activities in 2022.
The project has no planned activities in 2022.

Output 1: Peaceful co-existence between farmers, pastoralists and returnee communities enhanced in 8 localities of East, South, North and West Darfur, and along the migratory routes. Targets: 1.1 10 functional CBRMs in place 1.3 At least 20 conflicts resolved 1.3 10 events and forums 1.4 10 return communities with functional community policing system 1.5 10 farm protection committees in place.
Output 2: Secure Conflict-free land for returns and resettlement through joint dialogues among IDPs, host communities, pastoralist communities and returnees. Targets: 2.1 10 communities accessed 2.2 5 dialogue forums organized on land 2.3 5 arbitration supported 2.4 Support internationalizing 2 land information data centres 2.5 Land information data centres and establish the information update system operational
Output 3: Capacity of State institutions strengthened for effective planning and coordination of Durable Solutions processes. Targets: 3.1 Recruit 4 RRR/DS Coordinators 3.2 16 regular coordination meetings held 3.3 5 Inter-agency verification and assessment missions organised 3.4 Conduct Capacity Assessment of key institutions related to Durable Solutions, particularly Return and Reintegration 3.5 200 staff who received training and materials of which 30% female and 80% technical staff
Output 4: Access to micro-finance enhanced for improved livelihoods among vulnerable IDP and returnee producers, especially vulnerable women Targets 4.1 4 workshops organised and number of people trained 4.2 10 VSLAs established 4.3 100 people receiving start-up grants through challenges launched 4.4 Customised training and ICT equipment provided to APEX
Output 5: Support to stabilization of local communities through community empowerment and creation of livelihood activities for vulnerable groups, particularly at-risk youth Targets: 5.1 Capacity/needs assessments and capacity building plans for federal, state, locality, native administrations, and community in North and South Darfur 5.2 At least 2 productive infrastructure projects rehabilitated/ constructed in 2 pilot communities. 5.3 At least 4 CBOs in pilot communities develop and operationalize a sustainability plan in a participatory and gender sensitive manner 5.4 At least 500 at risk youth and women in each pilot community benefit from short term employment with linkages to viable business associations/microenterprises. 5.5 Establishment of joint committees between community and local police to foster dialogue and trust to support crime prevention and information sharing to foster mutual confidence. 5.6 Support to implementation of local peace agreements by the provision of peace dividends in the form of tangible projects as part of confidence-building.
Output 6: Rural Livelihoods opportunities for IDPS, Returnees and Host Community Members improved Targets 6.1 5 community productive assets established 6.2 2000 HHs supported in value chain commodities 6.3 20 producer associations established 6.4 Support for market linkage and value chain brokerage 6.5 1000 of vulnerable households supported to recover assets

• Detailed assessments were carried out by UNDP, Government counterparts, and Implementing Partners (IPs) in all the target localities. This helped to ensure effective targeting of activities and to align to needs on the ground. 1.1.1 Fifteen (15) Community-Based Conflict Resolution Mechanisms (CBRMs) comprising 253 members (211 males and 42 females) were established in West Darfur, South Darfur, East Darfur, and North Darfur. 1.1.2 UNDP organised a ToT training on peace-building and conflict mitigation/resolution skills were conducted for 253 members from the 15 CBRMs in North, South, West, and East Darfur states. The 15 CBRMs trained transferred knowledge to over 250 community members, including 12% women. 1.1.3 Community policing and engagement activities were implemented in 32 communities in collaboration with UNAMID/UNPOL. The first round of Community Peace and Social Cohesion activities, namely sports and games, meetings, debates, awareness campaigns, drama, and quiz were implemented in eight (8) UNAMID Team sites, namely Kabkabiya, Kass, Kutum, Menawashi, Saraf Omra, Shangil Tobaya, Sortoni and Tawilla, which had been attended by a total of 982 direct participants (647 males and 335 females) drawn from schools, parents, local leaders education officers, and the community members. The second round of community peace and social cohesion activities was implemented in 14 areas in Darfur states, namely; Tawilla, Sortoni, Kabkabiya, Menawashe, Khor Abeche, Nertiti, Golo, Kass, Shangil Tobaya, Saraf Omra, Zalingei, Kalma, Kutum, and Mershing. These events covered 1,545 people, including 959 males and 586 females as direct beneficiaries. 1.4 Two peace conference for reconciliation and peaceful co-existence among the tribes was conducted in Kutum and Alwhaa to identify the root causes of conflicts and to address the tensions among different community groups to achieve peaceful co-existence and voluntary return. It was organized in collaboration with The Darfur Peace Commission, UNAMID and UNHCR attended by 180 participants from the Native administrations, IDPs/Returnees leaders, representatives of women and youth, opinion leaders, executive directors of Kutum and Waha Localities, Leaders of military and police forces, representatives of UNCHR, the UNAMID DSRG, Madam Gbeho and UNDP, and the Commissioners of Darfur Peace Commissions (JRC, VRRRC, and Nomads). 1.5.1 Twelve (12) Farm Protection Committees (FPCs) have been formed and received training in Ed El Fursan, Assalaya, Edaen, El Fasher, Gereida, Alkuma, Kutum, El Genina, Beida localities. A total of 226 participants trained, including 6% of women. 1.5.2 A total of 33 mobile phone kits have been distributed to localities in North Darfur, South Darfur, East Darfur, and West Darfur. These include mobile phones, charging units which enabled the FPCs to communicate incidents in real-time and facilitated communication among the committees in different localities and communities.
2.1 Two (2) research studies were conducted in 17 Return and Host community locations to identify causal factors of conflicts over land. The communities were 8 in Kutum, Darelsalam, Mellit, and El Fasher Rural in North Darfur and 9 in Kass, El Salam, Gereida, Ed El Fursan, and Nyala in South Darfur. Key land conflict causal factors identified for address are (a) confiscation of land by nomads due to environmental degradation spurring pasture scarcity for growing livestock numbers; (b) shrinking fertile cultivable land coupled with increasing population need for food necessitating planting in the migratory route for livestock. 2.2 Based on the causal factors identified by studies, ten (10) joint dialogue meetings were held, drawing 177 participants (104 males and 73 females) in 4 sessions in North Darfur and 220 participants (173 males and 47 females) in 6 sessions in South Darfur state. 2.3 Training on conflict arbitration was completed for 131 active members (89 males and 42 females) and 45 active members (40 males and five (five) females) in the targeted communities in Kutum, Darelsalam, Mellit, and El Fasher Rural in North Darfur and Kass, El Salam, Gereida, Ed El Fursan and Nyala in South Darfur respectively. Arbitration committees were formed at 14 return villages (10 in South Darfur and 4 in North Darfur) to address land conflicts in their respective areas. 2.4 Four (4) land information data centres located in the state departments of agriculture and animal resources have been activated and being operated by Government technical staff. The centres are now functional and would help consolidate land information across the states. 2.5 Two (2) workshops were conducted on land conflict resolution and information management, benefiting 68 government technical staff and the native administration with 45 (40 males and five females) in South Darfur and 23 (19 males and four females) in North Darfur state, respectively.
3.1 Four RRR Coordinators were recruited and deployed in 2020 and support the UNCT, AHCT, and the VRRC in coordinating RRR and Durable Solutions Processes at Darfur and Khartoum level. 3.2 Thirteen (13) RRR Coordination meetings were held in North Darfur [5], West Darfur [4], and East Darfur [4] under the guidance of UNDP. UNDP also participated in 7 other Coordination meetings led by IOM and UNHCR. At the national level (Khartoum), four meetings were held under the leadership of the UNDP. 3.3 UNDP led six (6) verification missions in North Darfur, two verification missions, and one assessment mission in West Darfur. UNDP also participated in 7 verification missions in East Darfur led by UNHCR. 3.4 UNDP engaged the University of El Fasher Centre for Peace and Development Studies to assess key institutions capacity assessment related to durable solutions in the four states to identify potential hosts for land information data centres. 3.5.1 Assessment findings enabled targeted support to relevant institutions in support of durable solutions. The assessment prioritized the following: training has been provided in Proposal Writing, M&E, Report Writing, Administrative Skills, Leadership and team building, small projects management and planning. The center therefore conducted training workshop in the above areas for 23 government staff of which 40% were female. 3.5.2 UNDP provided 43 pieces of equipment and materials to the VRRC and other state institutions to boost their capacity to coordinate verification and assessment missions and information management and these include computers, field cameras, photocopiers, projectors, and printers.
4.1 A total of 6 workshops were organized for 300 Entrepreneurs on micro-enterprise development skills and practice of small business management in in East Darfur (Assalaya, El Daien), South Darfur (Ed El Fursan, Gereida), West Darfur (El Geneina, Beida) and North Darfur (Kutum, Korma) 4.2.1 UNDP established 34 Voluntary Savings and Lending Associations in East, South, and Central Darfur with a total membership of 1,700, including 80% women. 4.2.2 Additionally, five (5) old VSLA groups were re-activated in Um Sebeoikha villages in West Darfur. 4.2.3 The VSLA members received training on group dynamics, organisational management, financial and business management. 4.2.4 The VSLAs also received saving boxes and stationery and 4 VSLAs from East Darfur received seed money for lending to their members. The VSLA members underwent a two-day training in financial and business management. 4.3 Some 17 entrepreneurs were selected and supported with business start-up grants through enterprise challenge including grinding machines, start-up equipment for five restaurants, 12 youth supported with mobile phones solar charging system, eight women teamakers received grants to expand their businesses. 4.4 One data server has been procured and installed at the GDMFC office, and 15 desktop computers and six printers distributed to 5 subsidiary MFIs of GDMFC at the state levels. UNDP has also provided Information Technology (IT) equipment to support the capacity of the Apex.
5.1 Three (3) assessment missions were conducted at the community level in coordination with government partners. The assessment focused on Institutions working on the durable solutions process, mainly return and re-integration, to strengthen effective Planning and coordination. 5.2.1 UNDP supported the construction of a Health Vaccination Centre equipped with a refrigerator powered by a solar system serving about 2,300 individuals, including 1000 males and 1,300 females in Tura. 5.2.2 A water yard has been provided in Hilela community in the Dare Salam locality. About 4,000 individuals benefit from the water yard, including three other surrounding communities, Goz-Bena, Dagag, and Torondi. The water yard is constructed near a migratory route allowing nomads to provide water for their livestock. 5.3 Training needs of communities in North Darfur (Tura and Taufaya) were identified. Ninety (90) community members (11 males and 79 females) and 60 community representatives (34 males and 26 females) in Tura have completed training on small scale business proposal writing and reproductive health and gender, respectively. In Taufaya, training of 7 female Community-Based Trainers (ToT) has been conducted on COVID-19 awareness. In South Darfur, 34 community members (19 males and 15 females) were selected and formed into a Community Active Group. They have completed training on Communication, Leadership, Management and Conflict Resolution. 5.4 Some 3,000 vulnerable women and youth (55% female) were employed in a temporary labour-intensive scheme to construct the above infrastructure, which increased their monthly incomes by 70% during the period. Some other 200 people (63% female) were engaged voluntarily to rehabilitate some of the infrastructures. 5.5 Community Management Committees comprised 30 members (20 males and 10 females) in Tura, and 24 members (12 males and 12 females) in Taufaya, respectively, have been formed and are functional in the two communities. 5.6 The Project renovated a Community Center in Taufaya. The Center is equipped with furniture tables, chairs, plastic mats, one 900-litre water tank, and five 90-litre water containers for hand washing. The Community centre serves as a meeting place for the community during training and conflict management dialogue.
6.1 The Project supported the construction/rehabilitation of ten (10) infrastructure, including six warehouses, a livelihood hub, and three water projects benefiting over 13,500 households as follows: • In Allait, a warehouse has been constructed to support 11 Groundnut Associations and provided a safe storage place for 1,000 households. • The Project constructed a warehouse in Malam Alwidian which provided services to 500 households who are members of groundnut, hibiscus, and sesame Producer Associations. • Similarly, 1000 households are benefiting from a warehouse constructed in Kalimendo in North Darfur. The beneficiaries are members Gum Arabic, sesame, groundnut, and Hibiscus Producer Associations. • The Project also rehabilitated a warehouse in Darelsalam town in North Darfur. The warehouses offer farmers efficient and hygienic storage facilities that would allow farmers to access, sell or hold the commodities. • A warehouse has been constructed in East Darfur. • A warehouse has been constructed in South Darfur in the Gereida locality. • The Project constructed a solar-powered livelihoods hub equipped with furniture in Kalimendo, in North Darfur. • The Project rehabilitated one water yard in Taufaya in the Mellit locality benefiting 4,000 individuals, including 1,600 males and 2400 females. It also provides water for livestock. • The Project supported the Tura community to rehabilitate two water hand-pumps to improve availability and access to potable water for humans and livestock. The water yard serves more than 3000 individuals, including 500 males and 2,500 females. 6.2 Forty (40) Producer Associations were supported with production, processing, and marketing of selected value chains as follows: *Through a partnership with Darfood, El Fasher Research Station and Gazal Gazawat, 30 associations were supported in the production, processing and marketing of groundnuts, sesame and livestock, benefiting over 300 households in East Darfur. * Ten (10) Producer Associations in 5 localities including, Eldeain, Assalaya, and Abu Karinka in East Darfur and Gereida, and Ed El Fursan in South Darfur, received a one-week training on value addition and quality control techniques on targeted value chains. In all, 250 members (102 men and 148 women) benefited from the training. 6.3 A total of 34 Producer Associations, with over 3,000 members (52% female), have been established and trained in North Darfur (16), South Darfur (6), East Darfur (4), and Central Darfur (8). The Associations have been trained on business management and formally been registered with the Ministry of Social Affairs to formally transact business with microfinance institutions and other commercial banks to access loans to expand and improve their business. 6.4 UNDP has entered contracts with the private sector (DAL Group, DARFOOD) for forwarding purchasing of products along the selected commodity value chains. Another agreement has been entered into with the DAL-Group for the production and marketing of livestock. Overall, over 30 associations have had access to production support and distant markets. 6.5 More than 1,000 individuals/households benefited from business skill training and productive assets to enable them to pursue their livelihoods: * 163 households benefited from donkey 50 carts. * 300 individuals benefited from post-harvest equipment. The beneficiaries also received a one-week training on value addition and quality control techniques on targeted value chains. * Some 40 women representatives received support on handicraft and food processing. * 80 vulnerable women from Abu Jabra and Abu Karinka received cash support. * Some 30 women representatives have received support on the cereal trade. One group of 20 women received Cereal and Spices milling machines in Tura. * 350 from Baida and Geneina localities were supported with various productive assets, including grinding machine, solar charging systems. * A total of 4 plots were fenced with local materials in Almonjer and Kelikil villages. * One farm with an irrigation system established in Ed El Fursan for four women groups. The groups were supported vegetable seeds, farming tools and fuel. The groups also received training on vegetable production. The training was conducted in collaboration with the Ministry of Production and Economic Resources
